startDate.name: startDate
startDate.description: The first day to include in reports that are returned

endDate.name: endDate
endDate.description: The last day to include in reports that are returned

empty.name: body
empty.description: Bridge currently requires an empty JSON object for POSTs without body content

schema.description: Bridge POST APIs with no body content require an empty json payload ("{}").

post.description:
Send user credentials to authenticate with the Bridge server. Whether the server returns 
200 (user successfully authenticated) or 412 (user has authenticated but has not yet 
consented to participate in research), the response will contain a user session. 

The session contains the "sessionToken" property with the token that must be used to interact 
with other endpoints of the service. That value should be sent via the request header 
"Bridge-Session" to any endpoint requiring authentication. The Bridge session token is 
currently valid for 12 hours. However, your client application should be prepared to 
re-authenticate on any call if it returns 401 ("Not authenticated"), as the session may 
expire before this period for unforeseen reasons, like a server failure.

If the user has not yet consented, the session also contains detailed information about the 
consent (or consents) the user must submit a signature for, before they will be allowed to 
make further calls to Bridge. You can also implement logic to re-consent to updated consents, 
if desired.

404.description: Credentials incorrect or the user does not exist

post.description: Delete the user's session on the server.

Does not require authentication. Will send an email with a link that contains the session 
token necessary to reset the password (cannot be done through the API alone). If the user 
account does not exist, this method will still return 200 in order to prevent "account 
enumeration" security breaches.

This API will not normally be called directly by a client. A user will receive an email 
triggered by the /requestResetPassword call, with an URL to open up a password reset page 
on the Bridge server. That page submits the new password along with a one-time session 
token ("sptoken") to this endpoint, in order to change the password. The template for the 
email that is sent can be configured as part of a Study through the management APIs. If 
the token is not provided or is expired, this request will fail. If the user account does not 
exist, this method will still return 200 in order to prevent "account enumeration" security 
breaches.

400.description: The new password does not meet the password requirements of the study.

post.description:
Depending on the configuration of the study, the user will normally be sent an email with a link 
to verify his or her email address before the account will be activated. If the user account 
does not exist, this method will still return 200 in order to prevent "account enumeration" 
security breaches.

Only basic credentials are necessary to sign up (email, password and study), but all the 
information that can be provided for a participant's account can be submitted as part of sign up.

This API will not normally be called directly by a client. A user will receive an email 
triggered by the /signUp call, with an URL to open up a page that verifies the email was 
received at the provided email address. This page is on the Bridge server. That page submits 
a one-time session token ("sptoken") to this endpoint, in order to change the password. The 
template for this verification email can be configured as part of a Study through the management 
APIs.

Resend an email to the provided email address asking the address holder to verify their 
address. Whether the email address has been registered or not through sign up, this method
will return 200 in order to prevent "account enumeration" security breaches.

get.summary: Get a list of the participant's scheduled activities
get.description:
Gets all available, started, or scheduled activities for a user. Once an activity is 
finished, or expires (the time has passed for it to be started), it will be removed 
from the list of activities returned to the user.

parameters.name: offset
parameters.description:
The user's time zone offset (e.g. +07:00). Scheduled activities will be 
returned in the timezone submitted at the time of the request.

parameters.name: daysAhead
parameters.description:
Retrieve activities that are scheduled in the future for the indicated number 
of days past today.

parameters.name: minimumPerSchedule
parameters.description:
Force a look-ahead on repeating activities until at least the indicated number 
of activities are scheduled (this is applied to the each schedule in the system 
that applies to this user). The system will then return either the activities 
for N days, or the minimum number of activities, whichever is the greatest in 
number. This setting can help to expose infrequent tasks (weekly, monthly, 
etc.) to users.

total.description: The total number of records in the items list

post.summary: Update the status of one or more scheduled activities.
post.description:
Submit one or more scheduled activities with updated startedOn or finishedOn timestamps. The 
only values needed in the JSON for each activity are the guid, startedOn and finishedOn fields.

get.summary: Get a paged list of study participants (users)
Get user's participant record
get.description:
Get the current user's participant record. Any authenticated user may call this endpoint.  
**The user does not need to have consented to the study in order to access their participant 
record.**

post.description:
Update the current user's participant record. **Unlike most other calls in this API, you can send 
partically complete JSON to this endpoint,** and it will selectively update the participant's record 
(rather than treating missing properties as an instruction to delete those fields in the record). 
This means that many existing APIs that sent a single update value, can direct those payloads to 
this endpoint and they will still work fine. For this reason most `/v3/users/*` endpoints are 
now deprecated, though there is no plan to remove them. Any authenticated user may call this 
endpoint. **The user does not need to have consented to the study in order to update their participant 
record.**

get.summary: Get a study participant (user) record

post.summary: Update an existing study participant (user) record

get.summary: Get a study participant's upload history
get.description:
Retrieve information about the uploads from a user. This is particularly useful during 
development to verify the mobile application is sending valid data back to the Bridge 
server. The API can retrieve up to 2 days worth of upload records, defined by the 
startTime and endTime timestamps (ISO 8601 format). startTime/endTime are optional and 
will default to the last 24 hours of uploads. if the endTime is not provided, it will 
be one day after the startTime. If the startTime is not provided, it will be one day 
before the endTime.

parameters.name: startTime
parameters.description: Defaults to one day ago (24 hours)

parameters.name: endTime
parameters.description: Defaults to time stamp for time of request ("now")

get.summary: Get information about the last request made by this participant
get.description:
Retrieves information about the user agent headers and participant settings that were in 
effect the last time this participant contacted the Bridge server. Also provides the last 
time activities were retrieved and uploads were sent back to the server.

get.summary: Get paged history of activities scheduled for a participant
get.description:
Provides a view of all the activities that have been created for a participant. The state of these activities is 
returned without modification. No filtering is performed on the list of activities, which may have been assigned 
due to different or changing filtering criteria. These records help to determine if a participant is currently active 
in the study (e.g. if there are no activities, the user has never asked for them them). Records are sorted first 
by the type of activity, and then by the date the activity was scheduled to start on.

parameters.name: offsetKey
parameters.description: The identifier to use as the first record of the returned page of activities

parameters.name: pageSize
parameters.description: The number of records to return in the query (defaults to 10).

delete.summary: Delete all activities for a participant
delete.description:
Intended for use in development. Developers may wish to delete an account's scheduled activities in order 
to see the impact of changes to schedules for a study. Otherwise, activities from the original 
scheduling will persist until they expire, alongside tasks issued for the newly changed schedule. **This 
should not be called on production accounts.**

post.summary: Sign the user out and delete their server session
Trigger a request to reset password for this user
post.description: When called, a reset password email will be set to the email address for this account.

post.summary: Resend an email verification email to this user
post.description:
When called, resends the email to the user's email account, which contains a link they must 
click on to verify they control that email address. Account is not activated until this is 
done.

post.summary: Withdraw the participant from the study entirely
post.description:
This endpoint will withdraw the user from any and all signed consents in the study, and 
set their sharing status to "no_sharing". The user is withdrawn from all subpopulations 
in the study whether they currently apply to the user or not. Unless you have more 
complicated consent requirements (like an optional consent that can be signed or not), 
this is the best approach to withdrawing a user from a study.

post.summary: Re-send the consent agreement for this subpopulation
post.description: When called, re-sends a signed consent agreement document to the participant's email address.

get.summary: Get participant report records

delete.summary: Delete a record for a specific day of a participant report

post.description:
Endpoint for a worker to add a report record for a participant. Unlike other endpoints, 
the worker must provide the healthCode of the target user (this endpoint allows external 
processes working with data from Synapse to write reports back to Bridge).

delete.description:
Delete a participant report index. These indices can be shared between users so they 
are not normally deleted, but this endpoint allows the index identifiers to be deleted 
during testing.

get.summary: Get all subpopulations in this study
Get a subpopulation

delete.description:
Delete a subpopulation unless it is a default subpopulation, which cannot be deleted. 
If this is a

parameters.name: physical
parameters.description:
If an admin sets this query value to true, the subpopulation will be permanently
deleted from the database (used for testing).

get.summary: Get the participant's consent signature for the subpopulation

post.summary: Consent to this subpopulation by submitting a signature
post.description:
Agree to the terms of participant represented by this subpopulation, by submitting a 
signature to the Bridge server.

post.summary: Withdraw participant from this subpopulation consent group
post.description: This withdraws the user from only one subpopulation.

post.summary: Email the consent agreement to the participant's email address

get.summary: Get all revisions of the consent in a study's default subpopulation

post.summary: Add new consent revision to the study's default subpopulation

get.summary: Get most recent revision of a study's default subpopulation
Get most recently published revision of a study's default subpopulation
Get specific revision of a study's default subpopulation
Get a list of all consents for this subpopulation

post.summary: Add a new study consent version to this subpopulation

get.summary: Get the most recently created consent revision
get.description:
Get the most recently created revision of this subpopulation consent. This is not 
necessarily the published version of the consent.

get.summary: Get the published consent revision
get.description:
Get the published revision of this subpopulation consent. This is not necessarily the 
most recent version of the consent.

get.summary: Get a specific consent revision
get.description: Get a specific revision of this subpopulation consent by its creation timestamp.

post.description:
Publish a specific revision of this subpopulation consent by its creation timestamp. This version of 
the consent will be presented to users in order to participate in this subpopulation. If users have 
signed any other revision of this consent, the `signedMostRecentConsent` flag in the consent status 
record for this consent (in the user's session) will be false. However, the user is still considered to 
be consented and will not be shut out of performing operations with a 412 response.

delete.description:
This is a heavyweight operation; it is better to disable a user account when possible. 
This endpoint exists mostly for tests and cases where governance dictates the deletion 
of as much user data as possible.

get.summary: Retrieve the user profile for this account.
get.description:
Returns a user profile object that is a subset of the study participant record (which has superceded 
the profile along with a new set of APIs, see `/v3/participants/self`). Updating the profile will 
update the participant record, and vice versa. The user does *not* have to be consented to the study 
to retrieve or update the study profile (just as a user may submit updates to the study participant at sign up).

post.description:
Updates a user profile object that is a subset of the study participant record (which has superceded 
the profile along with a new set of APIs, see `/v3/participants/self`). Updating the profile will 
update the participant record, and vice versa. The user does *not* have to be consented to the study 
to retrieve or update the study profile (just as a user may submit updates to the study participant at sign up).

Change the external ID of this user. Note that this value can be changed through the 
`/v3/participants/self` API, using the same JSON payload defined here.

post.summary: Make user's data available for download
post.description:
Asynchronously request the uploaded data for this user, in a given time range (inclusive). 
Bridge server will gather the user's data for the given time zone and email a secure link 
to the user's registered email address.

Change the user's data sharing option to one of the allowable values. Note that this value can 
be changed through the `/v3/participants/self` API, using the same JSON payload defined here.

get.summary: Get a user's data groups.
get.description:
Get the user's data groups. Note that data groups are also part of the study participant 
record, and can be retrieved through the `/v3/participants/self` API.

post.description:
Change the user's data groups. Valid values must have been defined first by the study. 
Note that this value can be changed through the `/v3/participants/self` API, using 
the same JSON payload defined here.

get.summary: Get a participant report
get.description:
Get the records for a specific participant report. Participants can get reports for their own 
account. Note that this call does not require consent, but does require authentication.

get.summary: Get list of report indices for studies or participants
Get study report records

post.summary: Add a record to a study report

delete.summary: Delete a record for a specific day of a study report

get.summary: Get most recent version of each survey
Get the most recently published version of each survey
Get all revisions of a survey
Get most recent revision of a survey
Get most recently published revision of a survey
Get a survey revision
Get schedules for user
get.description:
This endpoint is the same as `/v4/schedules` except that any schedule with a cron trigger 
is marked as being persistent. This is for legacy reasons and the v4 endpoint should be 
used.

get.summary: Get schedules for user

post.summary: Notify Bridge an upload is complete
post.description:
Notify Bridge an upload is complete. Either a consented user or a worker 
process can access this endpoing, but failure to have the worker role will 
be treated like a consent error.

get.summary: Get status of a single upload attempt
get.description:
Caller must either be a participant getting a status of one of the participant's 
own uploads, or a reearcher.

get.summary: Get most recent revision of all upload schemas

post.summary: Create or update an upload schema

get.summary: Get all revisions of an upload schema

delete.summary: Delete all revisions of an upload schema

get.summary: Get the most recent revision of an upload schema
Get the specific revision of an upload schema

delete.summary: Delete a revision of an upload schema

get.summary: Get schedule plans
Get a schedule plan
Get all studies

parameters.name: format
parameters.description:
If true, anyone can call this endpoint and return a list of truncated study objects
(name and study identifier only). Otherwise, caller must be an admin.

get.summary: Get a study
Get a study
Get the public key CMS block for this study
SES email verification status
get.description:
Consents will be emailed from the support email address you provide. Amazon 
SES will ask the holder of that address to confirm this is OK.

post.description:
Amazon SES will attempt to verify that it can send email from your support email address. 
If that fails or expires, this API will trigger another request to verify.

get.summary: Get uploads for a study
Get external IDs

post.summary: Add external IDs to the study

delete.summary: Delete one or more external IDs

get.summary: Get the published surveys in a study
Get a schema revision from a study
Get all the non-session Redis keys

total.description: The total number of records in the items list

delete.summary: Get all the non-session Redis keys

post.summary: Updates the status of an export job
post.description: Updates the status of an export job on the health data records included in that job.

ABTestGroup.description: A list of these groups define the way schedules are allocated in an ABTestScheduleStrategy.

percentage.description: The percentage of users to assign to this schedule

schedule.description: the schedule to assign to these users

ABTestScheduleStrategy.description:
A strategy that divides users into groups according to a percentage scheme, assigning each 
group a different Schedule. The combined set of schedule groups should have percentages that 
add up to 100%. After the initial assignment, new users joining the study will be randomly 
assigned to one of the groups in proportion to their percentage representation in the study.

firstName.description: First name (given name) of the user.

lastName.description: Last name (family name) of the user.

email.description: The user's email address. Users can create an account in multiple studies on Bridge; these accounts are entirely separate.

externalId.description:
An externally-assignable identifier a research partner can use to re-identify a user's data 
in the exported data set (this must be provided by the application, it is not created by Bridge). 
If external IDs are managed, this is required on creation and cannot be modified after the 
account is created. Otherwise, it is a string that can be set to any value, changed, removed, etc.

id.description: An ID assigned to identify this user as an account in the Bridge system. This is separate from the healthCode and the two are never associated in the API or the data exported from Bridge. Used to retrieve study participant information through the API.

notifyByEmail.description: True if the user has consented to be contacted via email outside the application, false otherwise.

attributes.description:
A map of user profile attributes that have been set for this user (the attributes themselves 
must be specified in the study's configuration, and the values are stored encrypted in case they 
are personally-identifying information).

sharingScope.description:
How far does this user wish to share data?

|Scope|Description|
|---|---|
|no_sharing|User does not wish to share data. Note that in some early applications, this is the equivalent of withdrawing from a study, and should be treated as such.|
|sponsors_and_partners|Share data in data sets that are available to the study researchers and their researcher partners only.|
|all_qualified_researchers|Share data with researchers who qualify under the specific governance qualifications to access the study's data set. These researchers may do research on new questions after the lifetime of the initial research.|

status.description:
An enumeration of the status of the user's account:

|Status|Description|
|---|---|
|disabled|Account has been disabled. The account appears not to exist while it is in this state. Bridge does not automatically disable accounts for any reason, but researchers can disable accounts if needed.|
|unverified|Account has been created but the user has yet to verify the email address. The account appears not to exist while it is in this state.|
|enabled|Account is active and usable.|

On creation, the initial status of a user account depends on the email verification policy set 
for the study. If verification is required, the account will be unverified until that is done; 
otherwise it will be enabled.

roles.description:
The roles assigned to this user. Normal study participants do not have any roles assigned, but for 
developers, researchers, etc. their roles will appear hear (see main API documentation about the 
roles assigned by the Bridge server).

dataGroups.description: data groups to apply to this user

languages.description:
Two letter language codes to assign to this user (these are initially retrieved from the 
user's Accept-Language header, but are persisted after this as part of the user's options 
and it can be updated later).

id.description: An identifier assigned to this user, used to retrieve a study participant record.

creatdOn.description: Read only. ISO 8601 date and time that the user account was created.

status.description: User account status. `unverified` indicates the user has not verified their email address.

Activity.description:
When creating an activity as part of a Schedule, you will need to supply a SurveyReference or a TaskReference in the activity. When these are returned, any survey reference that points to the "most recently published" survey will be resolved to a specific survey revision (the one most recently published).

Tasks may be requested into the future by the client, and then cached. So if a survey is changed and published, it may be some time before participants receive the updated survey.

label.description: A label to show the user for this activity.

labelDetail.description:
Detail information for the activity (common uses have included indicating the number of 
questions, or the average time it takes to complete the activity).

ClientInfo.description: Describes the content of the `User-Agent` field in the format that is accepted and understandable to the Bridge server (see [REST API getting started](/articles/rest.html)).

appVersion.description:
The version of the application (must be a number, and should increase with every 
new release of the application)

osName.description: The name of the operating system (conventional names are "Android" and "iPhone OS").

osVersion.description: The version of the operating system (can be a semantic version such as X.Y.Z)

sdkName.description: The name of the SDK being used

sdkVersion.description: The version of the SDK being used

publicKey.description:
Base 64 encoded version of the public key for CMS encryption of data that is uploaded 
to the Bridge server. Each study has a different CMS public key.

ConsentSignature.description:
To consent to participation in a subpopulation (also known as a consent group), participants submit 
their electronic signature which can include an image of their actual signature. 

In addition, participants submit a decision on how widely they will share their medical information with researchers (see the scope property of the ConsentSignature JSON object, below).

How you describe this choice to participants is important if they are to correctly understand the consequences of this decision. We strongly suggest that applications present the following language to users when making this choice:

* **Option #1:** No data sharing. I do not agree to share my coded data (without my name) at this time;
* **Option #2:** I agree to share my coded data (without my name) with researchers at the sponsor institution, and their partners, in order to conduct this study;
* **Option #3:** I agree to share my coded data (without my name) with qualified researchers worldwide, for general health research.

birthdate.description: The participant's date of birth in ISO 8601 format (YYYY-MM-DD).

imageData.description: Base 64 encoded image of the participant's signature

imageMimeType.description: mime type of this image (e.g. "image/png"). Should only be present if imageData is present.

consentCreatedOn.description:
The timestamp of the version of the subpopulation consent that was 
presented to the participant for agreement.

signedOn.description: The date and time of agreement to this consent.

withdrewOn.description: If this consent is later revoked, this is the date of revocation.

scope.description:
|Enum|Description|
|---|---|
|no_sharing| don't share data generated by this participant (option #1, above);|
|sponsors_and_partners|share data in data sets that are available to the study researchers and their researcher partners only (option #2, above)|
|all_qualified_researchers|share data with researchers who qualify under the specific governance qualifications to access the study's data set|

subpopulationGuid.description: The GUID for the subpopulation of this consent

required.description:
Is this consent required? If required, the user must consent to it before being given 
access to the server (until signed, a 412 response is returned from the server).

consented.description: Has the participant consented to this consent agreement?

signedMostRecentConsent.description: Was the consent to participate made against the most recently published version of this consent?

Criteria.description:
Some objects, like Subpopulations and the schedules in a CriteriaScheduleStrategy, are 
matched against user criteria in order to return the correct object. The criteria 
against which user information will be matched are described in the Criteria object.

language.description:
A two-letter language code. User must declare this a language they can
use to match this object.

allOfGroups.description: One or more data groups; user must have all these data groups to match

noneOfGroups.description: One or more data groups; user must have none of these data groups to match

minAppVersion.description:
A map of operating system names to a minimum app version. User must send a version 
equal to or greater than this to match this object.

maxAppVersion.description:
A map of operating system names to a maximum app version. User must send a version 
equal to or less than this to match this object.

CriteriaScheduleStrategy.description:
Select the first schedule in a list of schedules that matches the criteria being submitted
by the participant. Criteria includes factors like the user's app platform and version, their 
language, and data groups that are assigned to the user.

DataGroups.description: A payload that contains a string array of data groups.

startDate.description: start date of the date range

endDate.description: end date of the date range

studyIdentifier.description: String identifier if the participant's study.

EmailTemplate.description:
A template for one of the system emails that are sent. In the templates, variable strings can 
be used to interpolate values from the study or the individual to which the email is being sent. 
The body of the email template must have a ${url} variable, this is where the link back to the 
Bridge server will be inserted in order to complete the email verification/password reset.

|Template Variable|What it will be replaced with|
|---|---|
|${url}|Where the link back to the Bridge server will be inserted in order to complete the email verification/password reset|
|${studyName}|The name of the study|
|${sponsorName}|The sponsor of the study|
|${supportEmail}|The support email for the study|
|${technicalEmail}|The technical support email for the study|
|${account.givenName}|User's first name|
|${account.surname}|User's last name|
|${account.email}|User's email|

Your HTML will be sanitized to remove potential security issues like scripts, frames or embedded Flash objects.

subject.description: The subject line of the email message (no markup allowed)

body.description: The body text of the email message (can be text or HTML, but the mimeType must be set appropriately)

sptoken.description: The token sent via email to the user that is needed to verify the email address is accessible to that user

status.description: Status of verifying support email address.

assigned.description: If true, the identifier has been assigned to an account, otherwise false.

GuidCreatedOnVersionHolder.description:
An object that describes the keys and optimistic lock values of a Survey. This object
is returned from create and update endpoints rather than an entire Survey.

guid.description: The guid of the survey (added when the survey is created).

createdOn.description: The createdOn value of the survey (added when survey is created).

version.description:
The optimistic locking version of the survey (increments when the survey is 
updated). If a survey is submitted with a version that is not the currently saved 
version of the survey, a 409 (Conflict) error will occur.

GuidVersionHolder.description:
An object that describes the keys and optimistic lock values of an entity (e.g. a 
Subpopulation or SchedulePlan). This object is returned from create and update endpoints 
rather than an entire entity.

guid.description: The guid of the entity (added when the entity is created).

version.description:
The optimistic locking version of the survey (increments when the entity is 
updated). If an entity is submitted with a version that is not the currently saved 
version of the entity, a 409 (Conflict) error will occur.

HealthDataRecord.description: See [Bridge Upload Data Format](/articles/study_design/upload_data_format.html) for details abot this model object.

createdOn.description: ISO timestamp of when the data record was created, as reported by the submitting app

data.description: JSON map with key value pairs representing the record's data.

id.description: A unique GUID for this record.

metadata.description:
Arbitrary JSON blob of record metadata, as submitted by the app. For 
ResearchKit-based apps, this is info.json verbatim.

studyId.description: Study that this record lives in.

uploadDate.description:
Calendar date in YYYY-MM-DD format representing when the server received the upload, 
using the server's local time zone (US Pacific timezone).

uploadId.description: The upload GUID of the upload this record is processed from.

uploadedOn.description: The date and time of the upload.

userSharingScope.description: The user's sharing scope at the time of this upload's submission.

userExternalId.description: The user's external ID at the time of this upload's submission.

userDataGroups.description: The user's data groups at the time of this upload's submission.

version.description:
A version number issued for optimistic locking of record updates. Should not be 
set when creating a new health data record. When updating a record retrieved from 
the API, the object will have the version attribute and this must match the last 
value issued by the service or an update will fail.

source.description:
An URL to an image. It is strongly recommended that the image be an SVG (vector graphics, 
re-scalable to the target device's screen size and resolution), at least 600 by 400 pixels 
in size, if not larger (some phones have screens of up to 800 or more pixels across the 
screen).

width.description: The width of the image in pixels. If image is present, this field is required.

height.description: The height of the image in pixels. If image is present, this field is required.

minLength.description: The minimum number of characters that's required in the password.

numericRequired.description: Is at least one number required in the password? (0-9).

symbolRequired.description:
Is at least one ASCII symbol (non-letter, non-number) required in the 
password? (! " # $ % & ' ( ) * + , - . / : ; < = > ? @ [ \ ] ^ _ ` {  } ~).

lowerCaseRequired.description: Is at least one lower-case letter required? (a-z).

upperCaseRequired.description: Is at least one upper-case letter required? (A-Z).

sptoken.description:
This is a one-time use token issued to the user to change his or her password. 
Normally this is emailed to the user's email account, using a link back to the 
Bridge web interface where it is extracted to complete this API call.

healthCode.description:
**Worker submissions only.** Developers submit report data to an endpoint that 
includes the user's ID, but workers processing anonymized data do not know a 
participant's ID. So the healthCode must be included as part of the report JSON 
payload.

date.description: The date (YYYY-MM-DD) of the report data.

data.description: An arbitrary JSON object containing whatever data should be saved for a report.

label.description: A label to describe this schedule.

eventId.description:
A string indicating the event against which a schedule will be schedules. By default if no eventId is 
provided, schedules are done against the date and time of the user's enrollment in the study. 
A comma-delimited list of events may be provided, and if so, the system will look for each event in 
turn until an event is found. If any event is provided, the user's enrollment date will not be used 
as a fallback, so this may need to be specified explicitly for some scheduling scenarios.

delay.description:
ISO 8601 duration string. An amount of time to wait before scheduling the first task. If the delay is 
zero or not included, and you are using an interval to schedule, then the first task will happen at the 
same time as the reference event.

interval.description:
An ISO 8601 duration, describing the period in days between tasks (it can be days, weeks, months or 
even years, but should not be smaller than a day). If this is used, cronTrigger should not be used.

expires.description:
ISO 8601 duration string. The period of time after which an unstarted, scheduled activity should be 
removed from the application (if it has not been started, no data will have been saved on the server). 
This is useful for recurring schedules where the user should not be prompted for a task or schedule 
until the next occurrence of the schedule.

cronTrigger.description:
A cron expression will schedule recurring tasks according to this standard syntax for describing event 
schedules from the Unix operating system. The format of the cron expression is the seven field format 
as described in the documentation for the Java Quartz Scheduler (note that there are other formats 
that take up to eleven fields, this online cron expression generator creates expressions in the right 
format). If this is used, the interval and times are ignored

startsOn.description: The scheduler will not create a task before this date and time.

endsOn.description:
The scheduler will not create a task after this date and time. **Note that 
this takes precedence over the minimumPerSchedule setting that can be provided via the API. Tasks will 
not be "topped up" to this minimum if they extend outside of this time window.**

times.description:
Required if an interval is specified (ignored if a cron expression is specified). An array of one or 
more ISO 8601 time values. This is a time of the day (without reference to a specific date and time), 
e.g. "14:00" for 2pm in local time. If times are provided, one task will be created for each time on the 
day determined by the application of the interval, for each activity in the schedule. If the schedule 
occurs once, only the first time will be used to schedule the task (and if no time is provided, the 
original time of the triggering event will be used; it's clearest to set a time).

items.description:
24hr time value(s) without a time zone (e.g. "14:30"). **Each time value will create a 
separate task, one for each activity in the schedule.**

persistent.description: True if schedule type is true.

activities.description:
One or more activities that should be done by a participant on this schedule. 
Each activity will generate a separate task. See Activity.

ScheduleStrategy.description: This is an interface for several implementations

ScheduledActivity.description:
Description of an activity (such as a task or survey) the study would like the participant to perform. 
A scheduled activity will contain a reference to a task or survey, but not both, and the activityType 
will reflect which property exists on the activity (e.g. if a task is defined, the activityType will be 
"task").

status.description:
The activities returned from this endpoint will be `scheduled` (will happen in the future); 
`available` (user can do the activity now); or `started` (the client has updated the activity to 
indicate it has been started). Activities are not returned from the API if they are `deleted` 
or `finished`.

scope.description:
One of three values:

|Value|Description|
|---|---|
|no_sharing|Don't share data generated by this participant.|
|sponsors_and_partners|Share data in data sets that are available to the study researchers and their researcher partners only.|
|all_qualified_researchers|Share data with researchers who qualify under the specific governance qualifications to access the study's data set. These researchers may do research on new questions after the lifetime of the initial research.|

study.description: Study identifier of the participant's study

SimpleScheduleStrategy.description:
The SimpleScheduleStrategy uses the same schedule for every participant. It is the easiest way to 
schedule activities and is a good place to start when building a schedule.

name.description: A label for the study. This will be shown to users in emails and other contexts.

sponsorName.description: The name of the institution or organization that is conducting the study. Emails will be sent "from" this entity.

supportEmail.description: The email address that will be given to study participants and other end user for all support requests and queries (technical, study-related, etc.). This can be a comma-separated list of email addresses.

technicalEmail.description: The email address for a technical contact who can coordinate with the Bridge Server team on issues related either to client development or hand-offs of the study data through the Bridge server. This can be a comma-separated list of email addresses.

consentNotificationEmail.description: Copies of all consent agreements, as well as rosters of all participants in a study, or any other study governance issues, will be emailed to this address. This can be a comma-separated list of email addresses.

identifier.description: A user selected identifier that is unique relative to all other Bridge studies (lower-case letters and dashes only). The identifier serves as a "domain" that scopes accounts to that study, and is usually created by combining an institution and study tag or acronym. For example, if your work at the University of Washington and your study is on Asthma in Children, your identifier might be uw-child-asthma. Users will not see this identifier.

version.description: A version number used for optimistic locking of the object these keys represent; this value must be passed back to the server on subsequent updates. An error will be returned (409 Conflict) if the object has been updated since it was retrieved by this client.

minAgeOfConsent.description: The minimum required age for participants in the study. If the user reports they are younger than this age, they will not be allowed to consent to the research.

synapseDataAccessTeamId.description: Synapse team ID that is granted read access to exported health data records.

synapseProjectId.description: The Synapse project to export health data records to.

usesCustomExportSchedule.description: By default, all studies are exported using the default nightly schedule. Some studies may need custom schedules for hourly or on-demand exports. To prevent this study from being exported twice (once by the custom schedule, once by the default schedule), you should set this attribute to true.

userProfileAttributes.description: Custom attributes that can be added to the StudyParticipant object (as members of the attributes property). This data can be personally identifying health information; it will be stored encrypted and in a separate data store from the participant's health data.

taskIdentifiers.description: An enumerated list of **unique** strings that can be used to identify tasks when creating schedules. These mostly serve to prevent typos when designing schedules, which would prevent client scheduling from working. There's no hard limit on the string content (e.g. "Tapping Test" is fine as a task identifier, as long as it uniquely identifies a task known to the application).

dataGroups.description: An enumerated list of **unique** strings that can be assigned to user accounts. These "tags" will be exported with a participant's health data to Synapse. This can be used to identify test users or specific cohorts in the study, but it should not include sensitive health information about participants. Strings must contain only letters, numbers, underscore or dash, and cannot (as a comma-separated list) exceed the character limit of 100 characters so they can be exported to Synapse.

passwordPolicy.description: Settings that will govern what is accepted as a valid password when users sign up for the study. If not included, the password policy will default to requiring 8 characters, including lower and upper-case letters, at least one number and at least one symbol.

verifyEmailTemplate.description: The template for emails delivered to users during sign up, asking them to verify their email address.

resetPasswordTemplate.description: The template for emails delivered to users who ask to reset their passwords.

strictUploadValidationEnabled.description: True if uploads in this study should fail on strict validation errors.

healthCodeExportEnabled.description: **Admin only; read-only for developers.** Should user health codes be exported as part of the participant roster? This identifies users in the public data set; this can only be set to true for certain studies where users expect to be identified by researchers.

emailVerificationEnabled.description: **Admin only; read-only for developers.** Should users be asked to validate that they control the email addresses they use to sign up for the study? True by default.

externalIdValidationEnabled.description:
Should external identifiers be validated? If this is false, then the external ID is treated as an unconstrained string. If this is true, the study designer will need to enter the list of valid codes into Bridge. Bridge will ensure that the following is true:

* If assigned, the ID will have to match one of the IDs entered into Bridge;
* A given ID will be assigned to one and only one user
* Once assigned, it is not possible to change or remove the external ID from the user account

minSupportedAppVersions.description:
Minimum supported app versions (older versions will be blocked), keyed by the 
name of the operating system (we expect either "Android" or "iPhone OS" in the 
User-Agent header of all requests sent to the server). Example: `{"iPhone OS":14,"Android":10}`

StudyConsent.description: For historical reasons, a revision of a consent document is known as a "study consent" (it would more accurately be named a "subpopulation consent" at this point). It is a revision of a consent document that is associated with a specific study subpopulation.

subpopulationGuid.description: The guid of the subpopulation to which this consent belongs.

createdOn.description:
The time the document was created on the server, represented in ISO 8601 
format (e.g. 2011-12-03T22:11:34.554Z). Each update of the consent document 
creates a new revision at a new `createdOn` timestamp.

documentContent.description:
A valid XHTML document describing the consent. In this document, the following tokens can be inserted and they will be substituted with the user's consent information when the consent is requested for that user:

|Template variable|Substituted with|
|---|---|
|${studyName}|The name of the study|
|${supportEmail}|The support email address for the study|
|${technicalEmail}|The technical contact/support email address for the study|
|${sponsorName}|The name of the sponsor for this study (the institution or research team name)|

**Note:** calls that return lists of these study consents do not populate this field. You must retrieve an individual study consent to get the content of the consent.

allOf.description: Full record about a study participant

healthCode.description:
Only included in studies that have been configured to return the health code, and only to researchers
through the researcher APIs.

required.description: is the user required to sign the consent agreement for this subpopulation?

defaultGroup.description: is this the default subpopulation for the study (there must alwasy be at least one, though it does not need to be required)

publishedConsentCreatedOn.description: the createdOn timestamp of the currently published consent for this subpopulation

consentHTML.description: The URL to the location of the published consent HTML document for this subpopulation

consentPDF.description: The URL to the location of the published consent PDF document for this subpopulation

name.description:
The name of this survey. The name can be changed after creation, and should not 
appear in the UI.

identifier.description:
A private name for the survey, only visible to researchers, used to identify 
the survey on export. It is recommended (but not required) that this identifier 
be unique for this survey type within this study.

published.description:
Is this survey version published? Once published, a survey version may not be 
modified, but can be scheduled for presentation to users.

schemaRevision.description:
The corresponding schema revision that Bridge server parses against to export 
to Synapse.

createdOn.description: The ISO 8601 date on which this version of this survey was created.

modifiedOn.description: The date and time when this version of the survey was last modified.

version.description:
The version of this survey as used to implement optimistic locking. This must 
be passed back to the server on an update, unmodified, in order for the update 
to succeed. If the survey has been concurrently modified, the update will throw 
an error.

elements.description:
An ordered collection of SurveyElement sub-types (the order the questions will 
appear in the survey).

SurveyElement.description: A survey element (info screen or question)

guid.description: A unique GUID for this element of the survey

identifier.description:
A unique identifier, assigned by a researcher, that is maintained through later 
versions of the survey. This is not as useful as the identifier which is exported 
for a question, but can be used to retrieve the screen for subsequent edits.

prompt.description: The main instructions or information text for the user

promptDetail.description:
Further information on the instructions, displayed in a secondary manner to 
the prompt (smaller text, more button, etc.).

image.description: An optional Image element describing an image to show for this screen.

uiHint.description:
A string "hint" to the user interface about the kind of user interface component that should be used to render the question (see values, above). The survey designer provides this hint, but the client application may ignore it or map it to a different set of controls, as desired. For a given data type, there is a defined subset of valid UI hints, which are detailed in the constraints model object documentation.

|Hint|Description|Conditions|
|---|---|---|
|checkbox|A checkbox that can be used for a boolean value, or for selecting zero or more multiple values from an enumerated list.|Question will always include an enumeration of answers to display.|
|combobox|An input that allows a user to enter free form text, or select from an enumerated list of answers. An alternative representation would be a set of radio buttons, with the last button selecting an "other" option with an associated text input control.|Question will always include an enumeration of answers to display.|
|datepicker|A control that allows a user to select a date (with no time of day component).||
|datetimepicker|A control that allows a user to select a time of day on a specific date. It should default to the current day and allow easy selection of a time of day today.||
|list|A control that shows a list, and allows for selection of zero or more elements. On some platforms, this is the same as a list of checkboxes (and in HTML can be rendered with a multiple select control).|Question will always include an enumeration of answers to display.|
|multilinetext|A control for entering longer texts, at least showing multiple lines for input and possibly also providing additional controls (such as a simple WYSIWYG editor with cut-and-paste support or spell checking).||
|numberfield|An input for entering numbers that includes "spinner" controls to increment or decrement a numeric value. The minimum and maximum values, as well as the amount the value is changed by these controls, should be defined by the minValue, maxValue, and step constraints of integer and decimal questions.||
|radiobutton|Two or more controls that allow for exclusive selection of one item from a list of choices.This can be achieved as well through a list where only one item may be selected.|Question will always include an enumeration of answers to display.|
|select|A select or picker control for selection of one option from a list of options.|Question will always include an enumeration of answers to display.|
|slider|A slider control for selection of a continuous value, like a decimal number, or a scale control for selection either of a discrete value such as an integer or a set of string values (where such values are ordered and make sense in this presentation, e.g. "no pain" to "extremely painful"). If used for an integer or decimal question, the minimum and maximum value constraints, as well as the step constraint, should be used to define the behavior of the slider. If used for an enumerated set of values, each discrete setting of the control (it should not slide continuously) should select a value from the list.|Question **must** include an enumeration of answers to display if the data type is not integer or decimal.|
|textfield|A single line text field. Note that if there are set values for this textfield, but the user can essentially enter an "other" value as well, then the combobox hint with a set of enumerated values should be used.||
|timepicker|An input for entering a time with no reference to the date of the time.||
|toggle|A switch or toggle control to select a boolean state||

label.description: The text to show in the UI (must be plain text).

detail.description: Detail text shown in a de-emphasized way near the label in the UI (must be plain text).

value.description:
The value to submit when this option is selected. The value is always a string, but should 
be convertible to the data type of the question's constraints.

image.description:
An optional Image element describing an image to show for this option. It should be shown 
along with the label (which will still be required).

SurveyReference.description: A pointer to a survey defined for this study, and associated with a survey to be taken as part of the mobile application health study. If the createdOn value is null, the the user should take the most recently published version of this survey (this is reflected in the href attribute).

identifier.description: The survey identifier. This value is required [TODO verify this is still true.]

createdOn.description:
The createdOn timestamp of the version of the survey. This can be null, which 
indicates the most recently published version of the study should be used.

href.description: An URL to retrieve the appropriate survey version.

operator.description:
|Value|Operator meaning|
|---|---|
|eq|equal to|
|ne|not equal to|
|lt|less than|
|gt|greater than|
|le|less than or equal to|
|ge|greater than or equal to|
|de|user declines to answer this question (it is being skipped)|

value.description: The value submitted by the user (as a string).

skipToTarget.description: The property will reference an identifier for a question in the survey. The user's next question should be that question, and progress through the survey should proceed from that question in the list. It is guaranteed that the referenced question will be after the current question in the survey.

endSurvey.description:
If present, this property must be true and no skipTo value should be provided. 
If the rule matches, immediately end the survey. (An alternative is to have the 
final screen of your survey be an info screen with a thank you note, and you can 
skipTo that).

TaskReference.description: A pointer to a task identifier defined for this study, and associated with a task to be performed as part of the mobile application health study (e.g. a walking test).

identifier.description:
The identifier that defines a task on the client. Note that this value is conventional; 
it needs to be defined for a study but has no further meaning on the server.

schemaId.description: The GUID assigned to this upload

schemaRevision.description: The revision of the schema that was used for this upload.

contentLength.description:
The size of the object in bytes. A standard HTTP header. For more information, 
go to [http://www.w3.org/Protocols/rfc2616/rfc2616-sec14.html#sec14.13](http://www.w3.org/Protocols/rfc2616/rfc2616-sec14.html#sec14.13)

status.description:
The status of the upload:

|Status|Description|
|---|---|
|unknown|Upload status is unknown. This is generally used for older data formats (namely, Upload v1), which had a binary complete flag rather than an UploadStatus.|
|requested|Initial state. Upload is requested. User needs to upload to specified URL and call uploadComplete.|
|validation_in_progress|Client process has called uploadComplete. Upload validation is currently taking place.|
|validation_failed|Upload validation has failed (see the validationMessageList for further details).|
|succeeded|Upload has succeeded, including validation. Note that export to Synapse is a separate step.|

requestedOn.description: The date and time (ISO 8601 format) that the client requested an URL to make an upload to the server.

completedOn.description: The date and time (ISO 8601 format) that the upload was completed.

completedBy.description:
Currently the API has an endpoint for the client to call and mark an upload completed. 
However, there is also a process that detects uploads to S3 and marks the uploads 
complete. This field indicates which client completed the upload.

validationMessageList.description: An array of error messages if this upload did not pass validation.

UploadFieldDefinition.description:
Note: For legacy reasons, this is the only model object returned from the API that does not have 
a type property reflecting the implementation structure of the JSON.

|UploadFieldDefinitionType|Description|
|---|---|
|attachment_v2|Attachment. When selected, `fileExtension` and `mimeType` can refine the field definition|
|boolean|Boolean|
|calendar_date|Date (no time of day)|
|timestamp|Date & Time (a timestamp)|
|float|Decimal|
|int|Integer|
|string|String. When selected, `maxLength` and `unboundedText` can refine the field definition|
|time_v2|Time of Day (no date or timezone)|
|attachment_blob|Deprecated|
|attachment_csv|Deprecated|
|attachment_json_blob|Deprecated|
|attachment_json_table|Deprecated|
|duration_v2|Deprecated|
|inline_json_blob|Deprecated|
|multi_choice|Deprecated|
|single_choice|Deprecated|

name.description: Field name. A schema cannot contain fields with the same name.

type.description:
Note that this class is unusual in the API in that type is not a constant 
"UploadFieldDefinition" value, it is one of the enumerated values and indicates the 
type of the field, not the type of the model object:

allowOtherChoices.description: Used for MULTI_CHOICE. True if the multi-choice field allows an "other" answer with user freeform text. This tells BridgeEX to reserve an "other" column for this field. Can be null, so that the number of field parameters doesn't explode.

fileExtension.description: Used for ATTACHMENT_V2 types. Used as a hint by BridgeEX to preserve the file extension as a quality-of-life improvement. Includes the period. Examples: ".json", ".csv". Optional, defaults to ".tmp".

mimeType.description: Used for ATTACHMENT_V2 types. Used as a hint by BridgeEX to mark a Synapse file handle with the correct MIME type as a quality-of-life improvement. Optional, defaults to "application/octet-stream".

maxLength.description:
Used for STRING, SINGLE_CHOICE, and INLINE_JSON_BLOB types. This is a hint for BridgeEX to create a Synapse column with the right width.

If not specified, Bridge will use the default max length of 100 (if applicable).

multiChoiceAnswerList.description:
Used for MULTI_CHOICE types. This lists all valid answers for this field. It is used by 
BridgeEX to create the Synapse table columns for MULTI_CHOICE fields. This is a list 
because order matters, in terms of Synapse column order. Must be specified if the field 
type is a MULTI_CHOICE.

For schemas generated from surveys, this list will be the "value" in the survey question 
option, or the "label" if value is not specified.

unboundedText.description:
True if this field is a text-field with unbounded length. (Only applies to fields that 
are serialized as text, such as INLINE_JSON_BLOB, SINGLE_CHOICE, or STRING. Can be 
null, so that the number of field parameters doesn't explode. This flag takes 
precedence over the maxLength value.

UploadRequest.description: **Important: Headers of the same values must be used when doing the upload against the pre-signed URL.**

contentLength.description:
The size of the object in bytes. A standard HTTP header. For more information, 
go to [http://www.w3.org/Protocols/rfc2616/rfc2616-sec14.html#sec14.13](http://www.w3.org/Protocols/rfc2616/rfc2616-sec14.html#sec14.13)

contentMd5.description: The base64-encoded, 128-bit MD5 digest of the object body.

contentType.description:
A standard MIME type. 
For more information, go to [http://www.w3.org/Protocols/rfc2616/rfc2616-sec14.html#sec14.17](http://www.w3.org/Protocols/rfc2616/rfc2616-sec14.html#sec14.17)

revision.description:
Revision number of the schema, used to distinguish versions of the same data format. 
When using this to create or update schemas, to protect against concurrent modification 
errors, new schemas should not pass in the revision parameter, and updates to existing 
schemas should pass in a revision number equal to the latest revision number.

surveyGuid.description: If this schema is created from a survey, this is the GUID of the survey it represents.

surveyCreatedOn.description:
If this schema is created from a survey, this is the createdOn timestamp 
(in ISO 8601 format) of the survey it represents.

id.description: The upload ID. The client needs to use this ID to call Bridge when the upload is complete.

url.description: A pre-signed URL for doing the upload. The URL will remain valid for 24 hours once created on the Bridge side.

expires.description: The ISO 8601 date and time stamp at which this session will expire.

messageList.description: An array of error messages if failures occurred during validation

status.description:
An enumeration of possible upload outcomes:

|Type|Description|
|---|---|
|unknown|Upload status is unknown (used for older formats and not likely to occur).|
|requested|Upload has been requested. The client has received an URL to post the data to, and the server is waiting for the client to call the upload complete endpoint when that upload has been finished.|
|validation_in_progress|Client has called upload complete and validation is in progress.|
|validation_failed|Validation failed. See messageList for errors during validation.|
|succeeded|Validation succeeded; upload has been accepted by the server.|

UserConsentHistory.description: A record of a complete consent (including both the dates of consent and withdrawal, if applicable);

subpopulationGuid.description: The consent group that the participant agreed to participate in.

consentCreatedOn.description: ISO 8601 date and time that the consent was created on.

name.description: Name as entered by the participant.

imageData.description: The signature image in a base 64 encoding.

imageMimeType.description: The IANA mime type indicator for the image (e.g. "image/png").

signedOn.description: ISO 8601 date and time that the consent was signed by the user.

withdrewOn.description:
ISO 8601 date and time that the user withdrew the consent, if the user withdrew 
from the study (note that later consent records may re-enroll the user in the 
study; nothing prevents users from joining and quitting the study, even multiple times).

hasSignedActiveConsent.description: True if the user signed the most recently published version of the consent, false otherwise.

UserProfile.description: An early user information object that has been superceded by the study participant object, along with a new set of API endpoints (`/v3/participants/self`).

username.description: Now always the same value as the user's email address

allOf.description: Information about the user and their session.

sessionToken.description: The session token that must be returned to the server to access services requiring authentication.

environment.description: This value should always be set to production.

dataSharing.description: true if the sharing scope is anything other than "no_sharing".

consented.description: true if all required consents have been signed

consentStatuses.description:
A mapping from a subpopulation GUID to information about the participant's consent status 
in that subpopulation (whether consented or not).

reason.description:
An optional, free text description from the participant about why they are no longer participating in the study. Some applications provide a more structured form to the user, and convert this to a text response.

The reason will be emailed to the consent notification email as part of the notification that a particular user has withdrawn from the study.

InvalidEntityException.description: A response to submission of a JSON payload that is not valid. The errors

offsetBy.description: The offsetBy value submitted to the server

pageSize.description: The page size submitted to the server

emailFilter.description: The email filter submitted to the server

total.description: The total number of records that match the criteria (may exceed page size)

offsetKey.description: If present, the key that should be sent in the next request to page forward one page of records. If null, this is the final page of records

pageSize.description: The page size submitted to the server

total.description: The total number of records that match the criteria (may exceed page size)
The total number of records in the items list
The total number of records in the items list
The total number of records in the items list
The total number of records in the items list
The total number of records in the items list.
The total number of records in the items list

startTime.description: The startTime value submitted to the server

endTime.description: The endTime value submitted to the server

total.description: The total number of records that match the criteria (may exceed page size)
The total number of records in the list

MultiValueConstraints.description:
User must select a response from a list of options (however the question can allow for a 
free-form "other" value to be provided instead if the user wishes). This is common question 
type with many possible UI renderings, but the constraints can help to limit the choices:  

|uiHint|Description|
|---|---|
|checkbox, list|`allowMultiple` = true|
|combobox|`allowMultiple` = false, `allowOther` = true|
|radiobutton, select, slider|`allowMultiple` = false, `allowOther` = false|

allowOther.description:
true if the user should be able to enter another value besides those provided in the
enumeration, false otherwise. If set to true, then the user's answer must be of the 
right data type, but no other validation occurs.

allowMultiple.description:
Can multiple values be returned as an answer? True if the client should submit multiple
values, false otherwise.

dataType.description: The value should be "multivalue"; **all the answers to this question are submitted as strings.**

step.description:
In increase or decrease in valid values, e.g. a step of 5 for a question that 
records weight to the nearest 5 pounds.

In increase or decrease in valid values, e.g. a step of 0.1 for a question that records
water drunk in tenths of a liter.

StringConstraints.description:
A string response. UI Hints for this type should match the intended length of the string 
and any constraints placed upon the length. 

**UI hints:** texfield, multilinetext.

minLength.description: The minimum number of characters that should be allowed.

maxLength.description: The maximum number of characters that should be allowed.

pattern.description:
A regular expression pattern (omitting slashes) against with the input 
should be validated.

allowFuture.description: Should this question allow answers in the future?

DateConstraints.description:
A date without a time value (e.g. "2016-07-28").

**UI hints:** datepicker.

allowFuture.description: Should this question allow answers in the future?

earliestValue.description:
ISO 8601 date and time value that is the earliest value that may be set for this question. 
No default. If allowFuture is false, that constraint will also be applied regardless 
of earliest/latestValue constraints.

latestValue.description:
ISO 8601 date and time value that is the earliest value that may be set for this question. 
No default. If allowFuture is false, that constraint will also be applied regardless 
of earliest/latestValue constraints.

TimeConstraints.description:
This is an ISO 8601 time value, in 24 hour time, milliseconds and seconds are optional, and there 
is no time zone for this value (e.g. 14:45:15.357). This represents a time of the day, regardless 
of where the user is, e.g. "I take my medications at 3:00pm every day, whether I'm in Chicago or Tokyo."

**UI hints:** timepicker.

DurationConstraints.description:
Deprecated. Use an integer value with a unit of measure instead.

Durations should be given as an integer value (not an ISO 8601 duration value). For the time being, a duration string is accepted if the duration is measured in the same time units required by the question. For example, if the question requires minutes, the duration string must be "PT120M", not "PT2H" or other equivalent values.

**UI hints:** numberfield, slider.

step.description:
In increase or decrease in valid values, e.g. a step of 5 for a question that records weight 
to the nearest 5 pounds.

410.description:
The version of the client making the request no longer has access to this service. The user 
must update their app in order to continue using Bridge.

412.description: User has signed in, but is not consented

403_not_admin.description: User cannot access this service because they are not an admin (no admin role on account).

403_not_admin_developer.description: User cannot access this service because they are not a developer or admin (no developer or admin role on account).

403_not_developer.description: User cannot access this service because they are not a developer (no developer role on account).

403_not_developer_researcher.description: User cannot access this service because they are not a developer or researcher (no developer or researcher role on account).

403_not_developer_researcher_admin.description: User cannot access this service because they do not have an administrative role (no developer, worker or admin role on account).

403_not_developer_worker.description:
User cannot access this service because they are not a developer or worker process 
(no developer or worker role on account).

403_not_researcher.description: User cannot access this service because they are not a researcher (no researcher role on account).

403_not_worker.description: User cannot access this service because they are not a worker process (no worker role on account).
